qas.question: What order is the breakdown field strength for air dielectric capacitors of?
Of what order is the breakdown field strength for mica dielectric capacitors?
In what way is the dielectric used in order to cause the absolute breakdown voltage of capacitors to be limited?

answers.text: The dielectric is used in very thin layers

qas.question: What is one factor that critically affects the breakdown voltage of the capacitor?

answers.text: the geometry of the capacitor conductive parts

qas.question: What is the difference in the physical attributes of the dielectric used in high voltage capacitors compared to low voltage capacitors?
What order is the breakdown field weakness for air dielectric capacitors of?
Of what order is the breakdown field weakness for mica dielectric capacitors?
In what way is the dielectric never used in order to cause the absolute breakdown voltage of capacitors to be limited?

plausible_answers.text: the geometry of the capacitor conductive parts

qas.question: What is one factor that does not affect the breakdown voltage of the capacitor?
What is the difference in the physical attributes of the dielectric used in high voltage capacitors compared to even higher voltage capacitors?

context: For air dielectric capacitors the breakdown field strength is <a0_0>of <b5_0>the order 2 to 5 MV/m<b5_0/><a0_0/>; for mica the breakdown is <a1_0><b6_0>100 to 300 MV/m<b6_0/><a1_0/>; for oil, 15 to 25 MV/m; it can be much less when other materials are used for the dielectric. <a2_0>The dielectric is used in <b7_0>very thin layers<b7_0/><a2_0/> and so absolute breakdown voltage of capacitors is limited. Typical ratings for capacitors used for general electronics applications range from a few volts to 1 kV. As the voltage increases, <a4_0>the dielectric <b9_0>must be thicker<b9_0/><a4_0/>, making high-voltage capacitors larger per capacitance than those rated for lower voltages. The breakdown voltage is critically affected by factors such as <a3_0><b8_0>the geometry of the capacitor conductive parts<b8_0/><a3_0/>; sharp edges or points increase the electric field strength at that point and can lead to a local breakdown. Once this starts to happen, the breakdown quickly tracks through the dielectric until it reaches the opposite plate, leaving carbon behind and causing a short (or relatively low resistance) circuit. The results can be explosive as the short in the capacitor draws current from the surrounding circuitry and dissipates the energy.
